findings.title: Missing lower guardrail for reduced.bond may allow validators to stake with lower bond than expected
findings.description:
The protocol lacks a minimum guardrail for the reduced.bond setting, which determines the required ETH bond per validator for node operators staking more than two validators.

The root cause is the absence of input validation when updating the reduced.bond parameter via DAO governance. While RPIP-42 specifies a reduction from 4 ETH to 1.5 ETH, the system allows the pDAO to set this value to zero or any arbitrarily low amount.

A malicious or compromised pDAO could set reduced.bond to zero, enabling node operators to stake with no bonded ETH. This allows them to earn commission rewards without financial skin in the game.

The impact includes increased risk of validator slashing and abandonment, 100% loan-to-value (LTV) staking, and erosion of protocol security, as node operators have no economic incentive to act honestly.
